clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Exercise Medicine on Lower Limb Amputees According to the International Classification of Functioning
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Exercise Medicine on Lower Limb Amputees According to the Three Domains of the International Classification of Functioning

lead_sponsor.agency: Cliniques universitaires Saint-Luc- Université Catholique de Louvain

clinical_study.source: Cliniques universitaires Saint-Luc- Université Catholique de Louvain

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether exercise medicine in lower limb amputees has a impact on the three domains of the International Classification of Functioning of the WHO (function, activities and participation), and on quality of life.

detailed_description.textblock:
Exercise medicine in lower limb amputees has a positive impact on physical condition and on some cardiovascular aspects (first domain of ICF). But as the investigators know, there is no evidence that this improvement is connected with a significant benefit on the performance of daily live activities and social participation (second and third domains of the ICF).
The investigators want to determine benefits of exercise medicine on all of these domains.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Timed Up and Go
Change in Satisfaction towards prothesis questionnaire (SAT-PRO)

secondary_outcome.description: measurement of distance between fingers and floor

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Prosthetic Profile of the Amputee

arm_group.description: Comparing the patients to themselves (spontaneus evolution) before intervention.

intervention.description: Physiotherapy three times a week for 8 weeks according to a well-defined protocol

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- unilateral lower limb amputation
- amputees with prothesis
- after learning how to walk with the prothesis
- walking with or without technical aids
Exclusion Criteria:
- previous exercise training
